text: If I speak up I will look foolish.
explanation: Assuming others judge you negatively is mind reading; it often exaggerates outcomes.

text: I always mess things up.
explanation: Using “always” is overgeneralisation — one or few events do not mean always.

text: They didn’t reply — they must be angry with me.
explanation: Guessing others’ feelings without evidence is mind reading; jumping to the worst outcome is catastrophising.

text: If I can’t finish perfectly, there’s no point starting.
explanation: Seeing only perfect vs. failure is all-or-nothing; predicting disaster if it’s not perfect is catastrophising.

text: One awkward meeting means I’m terrible at socializing.
explanation: Making a broad rule from one event is overgeneralisation; using a feeling as proof is emotional reasoning.

text: My friend yawned; I must be boring.
explanation: You can’t know their reason (mind reading); feeling insecure doesn’t prove the belief (emotional reasoning).

text: I felt anxious in the interview, so I definitely failed.
explanation: Feelings aren’t facts; anxiety doesn’t mean failure. Predicting the worst is catastrophising.

text: They corrected my work — I’m useless.
explanation: One correction doesn’t define your whole ability; seeing yourself as ‘useless’ is all-or-nothing.

text: If I make a mistake, everyone will judge me forever.
explanation: Predicting extreme, lasting judgment is catastrophising and overgeneralising; assuming others’ thoughts is mind reading.

text: They didn’t invite me this time; nobody likes me.
explanation: Turning one event into ‘nobody’ is overgeneralisation; imagining the worst is catastrophising.

text: I’m feeling low, so my future will always be like this.
explanation: Using mood as evidence (emotional reasoning) and projecting it into ‘always’ is overgeneralisation.

text: If they don’t text back in 10 minutes, the relationship is over.
explanation: Jumping to breakup is catastrophising; ‘all or nothing’ ignores middle ground.

text: I stumbled over a word — I’m a terrible speaker.
explanation: One stumble ≠ ‘terrible.’ That’s overgeneralisation and black-and-white thinking.

text: They looked away while I spoke; they don’t respect me.
explanation: Assuming intent from a glance is mind reading; there could be many neutral reasons.

text: If I can’t control every detail, everything will go wrong.
explanation: Predicting total failure is catastrophising; ‘every detail or nothing’ is all-or-nothing.

text: I felt nervous giving feedback, so it must have been bad.
explanation: Feeling nervous doesn’t prove the feedback was bad; feelings aren’t the same as outcomes.

text: They cancelled our plan once; I can’t trust them anymore.
explanation: From one instance to ‘never trust’ is overgeneralisation and black-and-white thinking.

text: I didn’t answer perfectly; they’ll think I’m incompetent.
explanation: Assuming others’ harsh judgment is mind reading; jumping to ‘incompetent’ is catastrophising.

text: I’m worried about this symptom, so it’s probably something serious.
explanation: Worry ≠ evidence; leaping to worst-case is catastrophising.

text: I didn’t go to the gym twice — I’ll never be consistent.
explanation: Two misses do not predict ‘never’; that’s overgeneralising from a small sample.

text: They praised others and not me — I must be doing badly.
explanation: Assuming the reason behind others’ praise is mind reading; feeling overlooked doesn’t prove poor performance.

text: If I feel unsure, I should avoid it — it will go badly.
explanation: Using uncertainty as proof is emotional reasoning; predicting a bad outcome is catastrophising.

text: I failed this task — I fail at everything.
explanation: Expanding one failure to ‘everything’ is overgeneralisation and black-and-white thinking.

text: They whispered during my talk; they were criticizing me.
explanation: You can’t know what was said (mind reading); assuming criticism is catastrophising.

text: Unless I feel 100% confident, I’ll mess it up.
explanation: Requiring 100% confidence is black-and-white; treating anxiety as failure is emotional reasoning.

text: A stranger didn’t smile back — people are unfriendly these days.
explanation: Generalising from one moment is overgeneralisation; assuming their motive is mind reading.

text: I had one binge, so my progress is ruined.
explanation: Seeing one lapse as ‘ruin’ is black-and-white and catastrophising.

text: My heart is racing — something is definitely wrong with me.
explanation: A sensation can have many causes; assuming danger is emotional reasoning and catastrophising.

text: They didn’t laugh at my joke — I’m not funny at all.
explanation: One reaction doesn’t define your humor; ‘not funny at all’ is black-and-white.

text: If I rest today, I’ll become lazy.
explanation: One rest day doesn’t predict a trait; leaping to ‘lazy’ is catastrophising and overgeneralising.
